>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/pfsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
Learn something new. De-botnet your life. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>Upgrade & Build Advice
Post build list or current specs including MONITOR: https://pcpartpicker.com/
Provide specific use cases (e.g. 4K editing, high FPS gaming)
State budget and country

>News
New releases: RTX 4090; AM5 / Zen 4; Intel Arc GPUs A770 and A750
RTX 4080 16GB (AD103) $1200 Nov Launch; RTX "4080" 12GB (AD104) unlaunched
Raptor Lake: K SKUs released + reviewed

>CPUs
For light usage, consider an Intel i3 or Ryzen 3/G.
For gaming, consider an Intel i5 (K if you want overclocking) or a Ryzen 5.
For multithreaded performance, consider an Intel i7 or a Ryzen 9. Get a Threadripper for heavy-duty workloads.
Avoid Zen4 (Ryzen 7000 series) - massively overpriced motherboards and poor-performing DDR5.

>GPUs
For gaming, check out the benchmarks for whatever games you play and pick whatever performs best.
For productivity, you will want to buy a Nvidia Card for CUDA, nvenc, better software support in general.

>Coolers
Hyper 212 EVO

>PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>SSDs
Use an NVMe Drive for your operating system.
Standouts: Samsung 990 Pro, Crucial P5 Plus, Kingston KC3000, WD Black SN770
https://ssd.borecraft.com/
Don't buy HDDs for a desktop PC. If you need large scale storage, consider buying cloud storage or a NAS.

>you can jailbreak an iPhone
ADB isn't jailbreak, since rooting or unlocking the bootloader are not required. It's a feature deliberately put into Android since the whole point of Android is being open and developer-friendly. This allows you to *uninstall* any app for your user, even the Play Store and Play Services, even the Location, Bluetooth or Call providers, even the built-in Calls and Messaging apps. Everything can be removed, no privilege escalation is required.

>nowadays
I moved from assembly to C back in the 80's, self-modifying code was a lot more common then. language constrains thought, and it's telling that due to the widespread adoption of languages that do not allow this idiom, that many developers can no longer conceive of a use for it. you see similar effects regarding goto's in users brought up with strongly structured languages, of dynamic typing in users brought up with strongly statically typed languages, and of complex linked structures in rust developers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89883044
>but I'm pretty sure the halting problem is not so general that all semantic, non-trivial problems reduce to it.
afaik there has not yet been a proof that the halting problem is in np-complete. memory safety is a specific instance of the halting problem, because violation of memory safety has a nasty tendency to cause the program to halt, however this does not mean that it is necessary to solve the halting problem to provide compile-time memory safety, as modern programming languages significantly constrain what you can express in that language, which makes the specific memory safety problem easier. Imagine a hypothetical programming language with constrained loops (for var in x or for var in array x by increment y), no heap allocation, no recursion, array bounds are range types ala Ada. It becomes significantly simpler to prove that a program in it is safe from a huge variety of memory issues, and that programs in it will terminate (even easier if there is no general while loop and no goto). This programming language is still useful and can solve many practical problems. But it probably couldn't solve all of them, its constraints are far too severe. And for most developers today it would be utterly miserable to program in.

**Python**: Not only one of the best languages for beginners, you can use it absolutely for most use cases, from science projects to web servers to scripting. They are recently working on improving its performance and deprecating old APIs. Also, they are adding true parallelism soon.

**JavaScript**: Only language that is native to the browser. The language improved so much you can barely compare old JS with its current state. Way too many libraries competing, you have all the choices in the world. You can use TypeScript when you need to too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89880917
>What useful tools or programs did anon make in FP?
I wrote a game in Haskell then had problems porting it to Android, which was one of my main goals. Even tried compiling it for webassembly or javascript as a cop out and such but it ran like dog shit completely unplayable.
Ended up rewriting the game using Godot.

I regret writing it in Haskell, but I did learn a lot and also learned to hate garbage collection which you have zero control over. If you have no way to reuse objects/records then GC is an absolute no go. At least with Java and other GC languages you can just reuse objects, but that is not the case with purely functional languages like Haskell.
There also is the lie that a sufficiently smart compiler is able optimize out garbage, but it's a lie.
GHC isn't smart enough.

Lessons learned:
1. GC is dog shit if you have zero control over memory.
2. Always test to see if your program/game will run on your targeted platform from the beginning (yes I was an idiot for thinking porting it will be easy because I used SDL, rewriting it was easier).
3. Functional programming and Haskell is nice but I prefer to have full control over memory and program flow.
4. Strict evaluation is preferable to lazy evaluation. Lazy evaluation should never be the default.

last_replies.com:
>>89880917

>>89883377
>the pixels are so small at that point that you can no longer see upscaling artifacts
the original resolution didn't change, anon. it's still, say, a 1080p image you're upscaling to your semi-infinite resolution. so are you really just going to use nearest neighbor and use that 300K resolution to display a 1080p image? hint: it'll look exactly like a 1080p screen would
and no, AA is not a bandaid and it doesn't add blur. it resolves the highest frequency image you can show on that screen without aliasing. the highest frequency was already decided when the monitor was manufactured, it's not like you can display smaller pixels by not doing AA, you can only get more aliasing. (at least in theory, practical implementations don't obviously always live up to this.)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89883399
Well there's no commercial display out there with PPI that high but I can give you an example.

Go emulate some retro game on a 300 or 600PPI phone. You can use the Sonic 1/2/CD remasters on Android for convenience.
These are natively 224p/240p games.
Stretch one arm while holding your phone as far as you can and look at the attract screen on Sonic 1 for example. You'll notice that at that distance you can barely see the jaggies but when you hold the phone with both hands to play the game from a normal distance you'll clearly see some jaggies still even though you're playing on a 600PPI phone.

>>89883516
>it'll look exactly like a 1080p screen would
Exactly(well almost exactly but I'll get to that in a bit)
Problem is upscaling 1080p on a 4K screen or an 8K screen is that you'll still either get some blur(bilinear interpolation) or jaggies(nearest neighbour) because the Pixel Density isn't high enough. With insanely high PPI you can use nearest neighbour and not having jaggies.

Now let's get into the "Almost Exactly" part.
You're almost right. And why do I say that?
While it's true that you're reconstructing a 1080p image it will still be better than 1080p on a Native 1080p screen.
Why is that? Because of Pixel Fill Factor
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fill_factor_(image_sensor)

What this means is that upscaled 1080p to 300K would technically look better than traditional 1080p since you have a much better fill factor which means far less(barely at all) black space between the pixels themselves.

>>89883516
>AA is not a bandaid and it doesn't add blur.
Wrong.
That's exactly what AA does.
It blurs out the edges of pixels to make them seem smaller.
Do you know how AA even works?

>it's not like you can display smaller pixels by not doing AA
Yes you can, that's the whole point of high resolutions/density

>you only get more aliasing
No, the higher the res the less aliasing you get.
But for lower res you need much higher DPI before you can see a difference.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89879694
I wrote custom functions and heavily customized my keybindings, but they are still based on the default ones.

I used Vim as my main editor for over 4 years, but after giving Emacs a honest try, I realized that I greatly prefer modeless keybindings. The problem with modal editing becomes apparent when you have short, alternating phases of insertion and non-inserting commands. This is easier with a modeless interface and eliminates the problem of pressing the right key in the wrong mode (which I still experienced in Vim from time to time even after years of editing).

IMO the relatively bad reputation of the default Emacs keybindings comes from two factors:
>most of them are deliberately mnemonic and don't care about the actual placement or other ergonomic aspects
>on the majority of computer keyboards nowadays, ctrl is placed in a rather awkward position

The former can be solved within Emacs itself, although it's not that bad of a problem IMO. The latter requires some other solution. I tried swapping Ctrl and Alt, pressing Ctrl with my palms, but in the end I settled on the common method of swapping Ctrl with Caps Lock. It may not be as good as having a more convenient placement on something such as a split ergonomic keyboard, but it's already way better than the usual position.

Swapping Ctrl and Alt forces me to curl my thumb to press Ctrl, which is not really that much better for frequent commands. Pressing Ctrl with palms doesn't work on many keyboards, such as laptop keyboards. Placing Ctrl on Caps Lock allows me to keep my hand wide open and press any chord with ease. It's also right on the home row and works with any keyboard.

Thank you for reading my blog.

HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i

There are no compatibility differences between versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try LibreOffice and set it to save as Office file formats.

threads.sub: State of write cache on ZFS
threads.com:
A fatal flaw with ZFS is no write cache.

If you have a large ssd and you'd like to write to it, while the ssd writes to spinning rust (so you get 500mb/s instead of 150mb/s), you can't. There are a few hacks, like bcache with zfs, but this is not easy to configure and has to be setup before using your spinning disks, and is hard to change setups.

In 2015 there was a talk on Write Cache for ZFS, but nothing has come since. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MkdrnG7GwdE

Solutions:
Should I use bcache, even though its very sketchy?
Should I just wait and hope ZFS adds write chache?
Should I just not be a pussy and buy a license for unRAID and be over with it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89882484
>all my writes are async so a slog will do nothing.
You can force all writes to occur synchronously, but that would be silly because it would be slow and you don't care about data integrity.
>I need a real ssd write cache with bcachefs.
Why? Writing twice is always going to be slower than writing once. If we assume that you have 10Gb Ethernet, that's roughly 1200 MB/s coming in, assuming nominal overhead. If you can write 500 MB/s to your HDD array, then you have 700 MB/s filling up your write cache. 700 MB/s will fill up 30 GB of RAM in about 43 seconds. In that 43 seconds, you would have written about 22 GB to disk. So after the first 53 GB of a file transfer to your NAS, you'd see your transfer rate fall by about 60% as you're throttled to disk speed. So for every additional GB of your transfer, you lose 10 seconds after running out of memory. You'd lose somewhere around 8 minutes in a 100 GB transfer. You could mitigate this with SSD caching, sure, HOWEVER, you could also buy an old 2U blade for $120, drop a $5 processor and $100 of RAM into it, and then you'd have 160 GB of memory to cache with. For $225, you'd get redundant PSUs, and full speeds for transfers up to 280 GB. How often do you send more than 280 GB all at once to your NAS? For that matter, how often do you send 50 GB to your NAS? Do you even have 10Gb Ethernet? It's entirely likely that you can't saturate your current system even with only 32 GB of RAM.

last_replies.com:
>>89876859
You can generally have shorter traces on a desktop motherboard, since you don't have to snake around a vapor chamber or other cooling, you end up with way shorter traces.
Most ram slots are right next to the cpu. In a laptop you are more limited with your placement because of cooling + slot hight (for sodim).
camm makes little sense in desktops. It's designed to take less hight than traditional sodim slots, and to allow shorter traces, both of which is not really a concern in desktops.
